Ron Rosenbaum is cultural columnist at Slate.com and the author of ""The Shakespeare Wars."" He joins us from our bureau in New York.
Nice to have you with us today.
Thanks, Neal.
And to begin with, it's hard to imagine in this day and age that anybody who really wants to read that sequel is going to be denied.
I think it's already been published in England.
And I think it's - the whole silly lawsuit about the sequel is a distraction from a really important question.
Salinger at one point was considered one of America's leading writers, one of the top five writers I would say.
That was - and he last published in 1965, a ""New Yorker"" short story.
Since then, 50 years, he's been silent.
And there are reports that he's been writing, and for all we know he's been producing the eighth wonder of American letters up there in New Hampshire.

But there's no reliable indication of whether he's going to burn everything he wrote before he dies or whether he's willed that, the way Vladimir Nabokov did recently, or whether we'll get to read what he's written and see whether a great American writer has taken a new direction or buried himself in his past.
As you mentioned, it's half a century since anybody read anything new by J.D.
Salinger.
Why do people care so much?
Well, I think there are two reasons.
I think there's a misreading of his original novel, ""The Catcher in the Rye,"" where everyone read it as a teenager and it had a charming teenage narrator.
And so, everyone thought that this was J.D.
Salinger when, in fact, often there's a distance between the writer of a book and his main character.
And they began to expect that J.D.
Salinger act like Holden Caulfield, and a cult grew up around Caulfield that, I think, caused Salinger to retreat up into the north New Hampshire woods.
And - but he, you know, his work, short stories and novellas after ""The Catcher in the Rye"" gave a number of people, critics, readers a sense that this was someone with a special talent.
And it's sad and troubling to see that the publicity-industrial complex, as I call it, that he's retreated from has caused him to keep the world away from anything he's written.
Well, you've made the pilgrimage up to the vicinity of his home in New Hampshire.
What was that like?
I wanted to, you know, I wanted to pay tribute.
I called Salinger's silence and his refusal of publicity perhaps his greatest work of art because he's one of the few people who has refused the whole Michael Jackson culture of celebrity.
So I drove up there, and I didn't know if I'd even find his house but a couple of local people directed me there.
And I got to the driveway, and I couldn't cross the line.
I couldn't cross the barrier.
I couldn't knock on his door.
I just felt too much respect.
And it almost indicated to me that there was a kind of taboo working that I didn't want to violate.
